abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Investment
            Promotion Project for Senegal were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was unsatisfactory; borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: consensus with regard to the content of
            project activities is critical to ensuring ownership and
            successful implementation. The project included activities
            for which there was no consensus among stakeholders. As a
            result some activities lacked the requisite ownership for
            efficient implementation. The objective was not achieved.
            Restructuring should initiate as early as possible during
            project implementation to maximize its impact. Following the
            lifting of the suspension of project disbursement,
            recommendations from the task team to restructure the
            project were accepted both by government and International
            Development Association (IDA) management. Project
            supervision requires close oversight, and active
            decision-making from management in light of early warning
            signs. Failures in project implementation were compounded by
            a lack of adequate supervisory oversight and management
            inaction when the situation warranted bold action. The
            capacity of implementing entities needs to be thoroughly
            assessed prior to project approval or effectiveness. Project
            implementation was significantly affected by the lack of
            technical leadership on the part of beneficiaries, who were
            intended to implement their own activities. Adequate
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework and impact
            evaluation mechanisms should be institutionalized at project
            inception. Project implementation and the ability to monitor
            and measure achievements were negatively affected by the
            lack of an appropriate M&E framework, and the absence of
            impact evaluation mechanism. Steering committee composition
            should be balanced and inclusive, and benefit from high
            level representatives able to influence and/or accelerate
            decision-making. In the early stage of project
            implementation the steering committee was insufficiently
            involved in project implementation and failed to ensure
            adherence to credit agreement requirements.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Private Investment Promotion
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This restructuring paper seeks the
            approval of the Executive Directors to introduce the changes
            outlined in the Development Credit Agreement (DCA), and
            extension of the closing date from August 31, 2010 to
            December 31, 2011. This restructuring is a level one
            restructuring due to changes in the development objective
            and in all of the project's four components which are
            being refocused to meet the revised development objective.
            The major modifications being are as follows: 1) increase
            the importance of component one. Improving the investment
            climate while focusing it on the most needed reform areas in
            light of changes noted since the project's
            effectiveness and the increased government clarity and
            commitment to investment climate reform; 2) re-launch the
            matching grant subcomponent of component two. Facilitating
            private participation and enhancing competitiveness, so that
            it operates, as originally envisaged, and fully complements
            the investment promotion facilitation that has been
            supported under the project and contributes meaningfully to
            skills development in small and medium enterprises; 3) focus
            the activities financed under the project component three.
            Stimulating sector investment and implementing policy
            reforms - by terminating project's assistance to the
            following sub-components which have been completed or will
            not be completed in light of an absence of consensus: (a)
            telecommunication reform and development of information
            technology sector; (b) postal reforms; and (c) edible oil
            sector reform; 4) revise project development objective and
            restructure, simplify, and update the results framework to
            target and better measure the outcomes delivered by each
            component and subcomponent; 5) extend the closing date so as
            to enable sufficient time for implementation; and 6)
            reallocate funds across the project categories to accomplish
            the proposed changes.

5085721.trustfund:
TF025641-PHRD-PRIVATE INVESTMENT PROMOTION,TF027832-POSTAL SERVICE SECTOR TRUST
            FUND - DEUTSCHE POST/WORLD BANK PARTNERSHIP
5085721.majtheme: Public sector governance,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Investment Promotion Project
            for Senegal's development objective is to create the
            conditions to stimulate a sustained increase in private
            investment through an improved investment climate, greater
            private participation in economic activities, and policy and
            sector reform. The project is expected to make important
            incremental contributions towards Senegal attaining the 8
            percent GDP growth called for in the Government's
            poverty alleviation program. The project will support these
            initiatives through interrelated actions aimed at
            stimulating private investment, and consist of four mutually
            reinforced components: 1) improving the investment
            environment by facilitating the policy, legal and regulatory
            interface between the public and private sectors; 2)
            facilitating private participation and enhancing
            competitiveness; 3) stimulating sector investment and
            implementing policy reforms; and 4) supporting
            implementation and capacity building. The project will
            finance consulting services, studies, goods, computers and
            equipment, vehicles, training and minor civil works repairs,
            and operating costs.
